title: Adding a Remote üåê
ques:
You have a local repository and want to connect it to a GitHub repository at `https://github.com/user/repo.git`.

Add this remote with the name **`origin`**.
explanation: **`git remote add <name> <url>`** creates a connection to a remote repository.

title: Pushing Changes ‚¨ÜÔ∏è
ques:
You have committed your changes locally.

**Push** your `main` branch to the `origin` remote.
explanation: **`git push`** uploads your local branch commits to the remote repository.

title: Pulling Changes ‚¨áÔ∏è
ques:
Teammates have made changes to the `main` branch on the remote.

**Pull** these changes into your local `main` branch.
explanation: **`git pull`** fetches changes from the remote and immediately tries to merge them into your current branch.

title: Fetching vs. Pulling üïµÔ∏è
ques:
You want to see what changes are on the remote **without** merging them into your local work yet.

What command should you use?
explanation: **`git fetch`** downloads commits, files, and refs from a remote repository into your local repository but does not merge them into your working files.

title: Checking Remotes üëÄ
ques:
You want to see a list of the remote repositories configured for your project, along with their URLs.

Run the command to list remotes with verification **verbose** output.
explanation: **`git remote -v`** shows the names and URLs of all configured remotes.
